Award.AwardTitle: Causes and consequences of variation in the hippocampus of individuals utilizing different spatial strategies
Award.AbstractNarration: Spatial memory use has been associated with many behaviors such as territoriality, mate choice, navigation and acquisition of food resources. Differential demands on spatial abilities have been shown to affect the hippocampus, the region of the brain thought partially responsible for spatial processing. Although many studies have found a positive association between space use strategies and hippocampal structure, little is known about the causes of variation in the hippocampus and if or how genetics, experience, hormonal and maternal effects influence this variation. More importantly, while most studies assume fitness consequences based on hippocampal variation, there have been no tests of this assumption. The primary goal of this research is to look at the genetic, maternal, hormonal, and experiential basis of variation in the volume, number of neurons and neurogenesis in the hippocampus, as well as the fitness consequences of variation in the hippocampus of male side-blotched lizards (Uta stansburiana). Consequently, this study has 5 primary goals: (1) to determine whether changes in the hippocampus are genetically encoded and relate to particular genetic combinations, (2) to explore if maternal effects, in the form of estradiol deposition in egg yolk, can cause variation in the hippocampus, (3) to manipulate testosterone in males to gauge if differences in gonadal hormones mediate underlying changes in hippocampal morphology, (4) to explore if changes in the hippocampus can be induced or enhanced by spatial use experiences, and (5) to assess if natural and lesion-induced variation in hippocampal attributes relate to fitness, namely survival. Thus, this research links the mechanism, developmental and fitness consequences of variation in the hippocampus. This study will provide interdisciplinary research training to underrepresented undergraduate students, as well as educating the general public via K-12 scientific videogames, popular print, visual media and presentations at community colleges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Only within the past 25 years have researchers truly discovered how much the brain can change in response to learning, memory, and even physical exercise. For instance, an increase in learning and memory can cause certain areas of the brain to increase in volume, as well as produce new neurons that integrate into the existing neural circuitry. This has been shown to be especially true with spatial learning, in that an increase demand on spatial processing produces an increase in the hippocampus, the area of the brain responsible for processing spatial memories. For example, London taxi cab drivers have to remember large quantities of spatial information and they also have larger hippocampi than people who are not taxi cab drivers. What we do not understand, however, is how other factors can modulate that relationship.

Therefore, the overarching goal of this project was to examine the genetic, hormonal, and experiential basis of variation in the volume, number of neurons, and neurogenesis rates in the hippocampus of the side-blotched lizard (Uta stansburiana), a species in which males maintain distinctly different spatial use strategies. The males of this species can be either territorial or non-territorial, where territorial males have increased demands on their spatial processing. Our previous research found that territorial males have larger hippocampi than non-territorial males, in line with the hypothesis that increased demands on spatial processing correlate with increased hippocampal attributes. During this funded project, we found that side-blotched lizards can utilize a spatial strategy during navigation but, from our common garden experiment, we found no evidence for a direct contribution of genetics to variability in our measured brain attributes. Our subsequent study did, however, find an effect of spatial use experience on brain attributes and this effect was modulated by territorial status, in that territorial males were more sensitive to alterations in the spatial environment. Further, we found a hormonal component contributing to differential neurogenesis rates between territorial and non-territorial males, outside of spatial area use. Thus, the results of this research indicate that several factors, including hormonal and experiential factors, contribute to differential brain attributes and that dependence on spatial processing (i.e., territoriality status) can modulate those relationships.

Results from two of the studies were presented at two national meetings. Seven publications have been produced during the past four years of NSF funding, with two additional manuscripts in the process of publication. The award provided training and mentoring to six undergraduate students, four of which are co-authors on publications and manuscripts arising from this research. Due to active recruitment, five of these students are from traditionally-underrepresented minority groups. Undergraduate students were involved in all aspects of the proposed work including regular lab maintenance, behavioral tests, sectioning brain tissue, immunohistochemistry, scoring brain sections, and data analysis. Also, this award allowed for collaboration between two different laboratories, as well as collaboration with a graduate student in the College of Engineering and a graduate student in Biology. Finally, we also assisted in the making of a short film on the field of comparative cognition by a graduate student. This film was entered into the 2012 Jackson Hole Symposium & Science Media Awards at the Jackson Hole Wildlife Film Festival in Denver, CO.
